sect1.title: Creating the Mobile IP Configuration File
sect1.para: This section explains how to plan for Mobile IP and create the /etc/inet/mipagent.conffile.

task.title: How to Plan for Mobile IP

tasksummary.para: When you configure the mipagent.conf file for the first time, you need to perform the following tasks:

step.para: Depending on your organization's requirements for its hosts, determine what functionality your Mobile IP agent can provide:

listitem.para: Both foreign agent and home agent functionality

step.para: Create the /etc/inet/mipagent.conf file and specify the settings you require by using the procedures that are described in this section. You can also copy one of the following files to /etc/inet/mipagent.conf and modify it according to your requirements:

listitem.para: For both foreign agent and home agent functionality, copy /etc/inet/mipagent.conf-sample.

step.para: You can reboot your system to invoke the boot script that starts the mipagent daemon. Or, you can also start mipagent by typing the following command:

task.title: How to Create the Mobile IP Configuration File

step.para: Assume the Primary Administrator role, or become superuser, on the system where you want to enable Mobile IP.

The Primary Administrator role includes the Primary Administrator profile. To create the role and assign the role to a user, see Chapter 2, Working With the Solaris Management Console (Tasks), in System Administration Guide: Basic Administration.
Create the /etc/inet/mipagent.conf file by using one of the following options:

listitem.para: In the /etc/inet directory, create an empty file named mipagent.conf.
From the following list, copy the sample file that provides the functionality you want for the /etc/inet/mipagent.conf file.

step.para: Add or change configuration parameters in the /etc/inet/mipagent.conf file to conform to your configuration requirements.
The remaining procedures in this section describe the steps to modify sections in /etc/inet/mipagent.conf.

task.title: How to Configure the Advertisements Section

tasksummary.para: Advertisements Section provides descriptions of the labels and values that are used in this section.

step.para: Edit the /etc/inet/mipagent.conf file and add or change the following lines by using the values that are required for your configuration.
step.screen: [Advertisements interface] HomeAgent = <yes/no> ForeignAgent = <yes/no> PrefixFlags = <yes/no> AdvertiseOnBcast = <yes/no> RegLifetime = n AdvLifetime = n AdvFrequency = n ReverseTunnel = <yes/no/FA/HA/both> ReverseTunnelRequired = <yes/no/FA/HA>

note.para: You must include a different Advertisements section for each interface on the local host that provides Mobile IP services.

task.title: How to Configure the GlobalSecurityParameters Section

tasksummary.para: GlobalSecurityParameters Section provides descriptions of the labels and values that are used in this section.

step.para: Edit the /etc/inet/mipagent.conf file and add or change the following lines by using the values that are required for your configuration:
step.screen: [GlobalSecurityParameters] MaxClockSkew = n HA-FAauth = <yes/no> MN-FAauth = <yes/no> Challenge = <yes/no> KeyDistribution = files

task.title: How to Configure the Address Section

tasksummary.para: Address Section provides descriptions of the labels and values that are used in this section.

step.para: Edit the /etc/inet/mipagent.conf file.
Add or change the following lines by using the values that are required for your configuration:

para.emphasis: For a mobile node, use the following:
For an agent, use the following:

listitem.screen: [Address address] Type = agent SPI = SPI-identifier IPsecRequest = action {properties} [: action {properties}] IPsecReply = action {properties} [: action {properties}] IPsecTunnel = action {properties} [: action {properties}]
listitem.para: where action and {properties} are any action and associated properties that are defined in the ipsec7P man page.

note.para: The SPI that is configured previously corresponds to the MD5 protection mechanism that is required by RFC 2002. The SPI that is configured previously does not correspond to the SPI that is used by IPsec. For more information about IPsec, see Chapter 19, IP Security Architecture (Overview) and Chapter 20, Configuring IPsec (Tasks). Also see the ipsec7P man page.

para.emphasis: For a mobile node that is identified by its NAI, use the following:

listitem.screen: [Address NAI] Type = Node SPI = SPI-identifier Pool = pool-identifier

para.emphasis: For a default mobile node, use the following:

listitem.screen: [Address Node-Default] Type = Node SPI = SPI-identifier Pool = pool-identifier

sect1.title: Modifying the Mobile IP Configuration File
sect1.para: This section shows you how to modify the Mobile IP configuration file by using the mipagentconfig command. This section also shows you how to display the current settings of parameter destinations.
Configuring the Mobility IP Agent provides a conceptual description of the mipagentconfig command's usage. You can also review the mipagentconfig1M man page.

sect1.title: Displaying Mobility Agent Status
sect1.para: You can use the mipagentstat command to display a foreign agent's visitors list and a home agent's binding table. Mobile IP Mobility Agent Status provides a conceptual description of the mipagentstat command. You can also review the mipagentstat1M man page.

task.title: How to Display Mobility Agent Status

step.para: Become superuser or assume an equivalent role on the system where you are enabling Mobile IP.
Roles contain authorizations and privileged commands. For more information about roles, see Configuring RBAC (Task Map) in System Administration Guide: Security Services.
Display the mobility agent status.

listitem.para: Shows the list of active mobile nodes in the foreign agent's visitor list.
Shows the list of active mobile nodes in the home agent's binding table.
Shows the list of security associations with an agent's mobility agent peers.

example.title: Displaying Mobility Agent Status
example.para: This example shows how to display the visitor list for all mobile nodes that are registered with a foreign agent.
As a result, output similar to the following is displayed:
example.screen: Mobile Node Home Agent Time (s) Time (s) Flags Granted Remaining --------------- -------------- ------------ --------- ----- foobar.xyz.com ha1.xyz.com 600 125 .....T. 10.1.5.23 10.1.5.1 1000 10 .....T.
example.para: This example shows how to display foreign agent security associations.
As a result, output similar to the following is displayed:
example.screen: Foreign ..... Security Association(s)..... Agent Requests Replies FTunnel RTunnel ---------------------- -------- -------- -------- -------- forn-agent.eng.sun.com AH AH ESP ESP

sect1.title: Displaying Mobility Routes on a Foreign Agent
sect1.para: You can use the netstat command to display additional information about source-specific routes that are created by forward tunnels and reverse tunnels. See the netstat(1M) man page for more information about this command.

task.title: How to Display Mobility Routes on a Foreign Agent

step.para: Become superuser or assume an equivalent role on the system where you are enabling Mobile IP.
Roles contain authorizations and privileged commands. For more information about roles, see Configuring RBAC (Task Map) in System Administration Guide: Security Services.
Display the mobility routes.

example.title: Displaying Mobility Routes on a Foreign Agent
example.para: The following example shows the routes for a foreign agent that uses a reverse tunnel.
example.screen: Routing Table: IPv4 Source-Specific Destination In If Source Gateway Flags Use Out If -------------- ------- ------------ --------- ----- ---- ------- 10.6.32.11 ip.tun1 -- 10.6.32.97 UH 0 hme1 -- hme1 10.6.32.11 -- U 0 ip.tun1
example.para: The first line indicates that the destination IP address 10.6.32.11 and the incoming interface ip.tun1 select hme1 as the interface that forwards the packets. The next line indicates that any packet originating from interface hme1 and source address 10.6.32.11 must be forwarded to ip.tun1.
